factoid: Pierre returned home and was handed two of Count Rostopchín’s broadsheets that had been brought that day.
The first broadsheet declared that the report that Count Rostopchín had forbidden people to leave Moscow was false.
The first broadsheet declared that Count Rostopchín was glad that ladies and tradesmen’s wives were leaving Moscow.
The first broadsheet said, "There will be less panic and less gossip."
The first broadsheet said, "I will stake my life on it that that scoundrel will not enter Moscow."
These words showed Pierre that the French would enter Moscow.
The second broadsheet stated that the headquarters were at Vyázma.
The second broadsheet stated that Count Wittgenstein had defeated the French.
The second broadsheet stated that as many inhabitants of Moscow wished to be armed, weapons were ready at the arsenal.
The arsenal contained sabers, pistols, and muskets.
The arsenal weapons could be had at a low price.
Pierre pondered over the broadsheets.
Pierre asked himself, "Shall I join the army and enter the service, or wait?"
Pierre took a pack of cards from the table and began to lay them out for a game of patience.
Pierre said to himself, "If this patience comes out, it means… what does it mean?"
Pierre had not decided what it should mean when he heard the voice of the eldest princess at the door asking whether she might come in.
Pierre said to himself, "Then it will mean that I must go to the army."
Pierre said to the eldest princess, "Come in, come in!"
Only the eldest princess was still living in Pierre’s house.
The two younger princesses had both married.
The eldest princess said, "Excuse my coming to you, cousin."
The eldest princess said, "You know some decision must be come to."
The eldest princess asked, "What is going to happen? Everyone has left Moscow and the people are rioting. How is it that we are staying on?"
Pierre said, "On the contrary, things seem satisfactory, ma cousine."
Pierre said, "Satisfactory, indeed! Very satisfactory!"
Pierre said, "Barbara Ivánovna told me today how our troops are distinguishing themselves."
Pierre said, "It certainly does them credit!"
Pierre said, "And the people too are quite mutinous—they no longer obey, even my maid has taken to being rude."
Pierre said, "At this rate they will soon begin beating us."
Pierre said, "One can’t walk in the streets."
Pierre said, "But, above all, the French will be here any day now, so what are we waiting for?"
The eldest princess said, "I ask just one thing of you, cousin, arrange for me to be taken to Petersburg."
The eldest princess said, "Whatever I may be, I can’t live under Bonaparte’s rule."
The eldest princess said, "I won’t submit to your Napoleon! Others may if they please."
The eldest princess said, "If you don’t want to do this…"
The eldest princess said, "But I will, I’ll give the order at once."
The eldest princess was apparently vexed at not having anyone to be angry with.
The eldest princess muttered to herself and sat down on a chair.
Pierre said, "But you have been misinformed."
Pierre said, "Everything is quiet in the city and there is not the slightest danger."
Pierre said, "See! I’ve just been reading…"
Pierre showed the eldest princess the broadsheet.
Pierre said, "Count Rostopchín writes that he will stake his life on it that the enemy will not enter Moscow."
The eldest princess said, "Oh, that count of yours!"
The eldest princess said, "He is a hypocrite, a rascal who has himself roused the people to riot."
The eldest princess said, "Didn’t he write in those idiotic broadsheets that anyone, ‘whoever it might be, should be dragged to the lockup by his hair’?"
The eldest princess said, "And honor and glory to whoever captures him."
The eldest princess said, "This is what his cajolery has brought us to!"
The eldest princess said, "Barbara Ivánovna told me the mob near killed her because she said something in French."
